awd_titl_txt: Switching beyond the Molecule using Hydrazones
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of molecular switches and machines is a vital part of the current scientific drive towards miniaturization. Appreciable advances have been made in recent years in the design of new molecular switches, integrating them into bulk materials, and applying them in new functions. However, there are still many challenges that need to be addressed before such systems can find their way into real-life applications. This research addresses one of these issues, which is the lack of a basic understanding of how to make molecular switches and machines work together towards a useful goal - a solved problem in natural biological systems. To mimic Nature, the Aprahamian research group at Dartmouth College studies the interactions of molecular switches with their environment. This knowledge may lead to the engineering of dynamic, adaptive and self-regulating molecular assemblies that can be used in drug delivery and energy-related applications. The broader impacts of this research include participation in the American Chemical Society's SEED Program and other endeavors to help retain students at different levels of education (high school, undergraduate, and graduate students) in the sciences.  Professor Aprahamian also uses interactive demonstrations to educate the public about important concepts related to supramolecular chemistry. These activities are expected to strengthen and extend the group's informal and formal science education partnerships and networks with local schools and science museums.

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, this research examines the coupling of zinc(II)-initiated, coordination-coupled, deprotonation (CCD) of hydrazone switches with other metals, particularly palladium(II).  These reactions extend the capabilities of currently known switching cascades and open the way for compartmentalization driven catalysis using self-assembled cages.  The Aprahamian group gains a deeper understanding of the factors that control CCD-enabled negative feedback loops and uncovers the underlying rules that lead to analyte regulation. Finally, the group develops new zinc(II) photocages/switches that can couple with CCD and feedback loops to enable the future design of oscillating systems, molecular clocks, and self-regulating assemblies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project "Switching beyond the Molecule using Hydrazones" was focused on developing structurally simple hydrazone-based switches that can be activated with chemical and light stimuli, and using them in different applications. For example, we studied how strain influences the thermal stability of the switches and found that larger bridging units (i.e., alkyl chains) actually accelerate the process. This unusual process was attributed to interactions between the bridging units that result in strain. We then took advantage of the accumulated strain to design molecules that can harvest and store light energy, which then can be released on command. Such molecules are promising for use in future battery and energy storage devices. After optimizing the properties of the photo-switches we used a derivative to template the synthesis of g-cyclodextrin (g-CD), which is a donut shaped-molecule that can bind other molecules in its cavity. The photoremovable template increased the synthetic yield of g-CD by 6-fold and allowed us to isolate the product without using the expensive steam distillation process used in industry. We also studied the effect of the environment, whether metal surfaces or the void of a covalent organic framework, effect the switching efficiency of the switches. We also developed a supramolecular drug delivery system using the hydrazones, which enabled us to release, track and quantify the amount of drug being released. As for the chemically activated systems, we developed a cascade reaction involving two metals and a proton relay that result in the activation of three different switches. We also gained insights on what controls the threshold of the negative feedback loop that was developed in the group. 

The broader impact of this project lies in developing a better understanding of how strain can build-up in molecules, and how to tap into the strain for useful energy related applications. We also gained a better understand of how to control the properties on different molecules in various environments, and how to make such molecules “talk” with one another. Finally, the photo-templation strategy can open the way for drastically lowering the production cost of g-CD, which will enable its use in various industries and applications (e.g., pharmaceutical industries, cosmetic products, and pollutant remediation).

 

Significantly, the most important impact of this grant was the training of high-school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students, who came from a diverse pool of backgrounds, in supramolecular, organic and materials chemistry, in addition to various characterization techniques. This training equipped the students for graduate school and positions in industry, and academia. Moreover, this grant enabled us to interact with the general public through our numerous outreach events, which broadened the reach of the science we are conducting in the laboratory.     

 


Last Modified: 10/23/2022
Modified by: Ivan Aprahamian
